abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: In colorectal cancer (CRC), RNF43 mutations are linked to BRAF V600E-initiated serrated adenomas that advance into mucinous adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis upon metastasis. How RNF43 mutations facilitate a metastasis-prone growth state remains unknown. Here, we addressed this issue by repairing mutant RNF43 in patient-derived BRAF-mutant CRC organoids using gene editing. Upon RNF43 correction, CRC organoids exhibit strongly decreased mucus production and, moreover, display loss of niche factor independence and metastatic capacity upon orthotopic transplantation in mice. Mechanistically, we show that mutant RNF43 promotes cancer cell lineage specification towards a non-dividing niche population that secretes essential growth factors, providing a state of self-sufficiency to the cancer epithelium. We show that phenotypic diversification into tumour-intrinsic niche cells (TINCs) and proliferative cancer stem cells depends on tuneable WNT levels enabled by mutations in RNF43, but not APC. In patient samples, enhanced TINC profiles correlate with RNF43-mutant CRC, mucinous histology and metastatic disease, thus representing a general cellular mechanism by which tumours acquire a self-sufficient, pro-metastatic growth state.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Self-renewal of human colon adult stem cells is controlled by specialized epithelial and mesenchymal niche cells that secrete essential factors to promote growth and prevent differentiation1. Identification of the essential stem-cell niche factors such as WNT, EGF and BMP-antagonists has led to the establishment of in vitro culture conditions for intestinal organoids2. Different from healthy adult colon stem cells, patient-derived colorectal cancer (CRC) cells commonly display loss of niche factor-dependency during in vitro outgrowth into organoids, which correlates with their metastatic capacity in vivo3,4. In the classical view, the adenoma-carcinoma transition is driven by an accumulation of mutations (e.g. APC/KRAS/SMAD) that endow tumour cells with stem cell-like properties while omitting the need for a specialized niche3–5.

CRC is however a heterogeneous disease and can develop via two mutually exclusive genetic pathways with distinct molecular and clinical manifestations6–9. 15-30% of sporadic CRCs develop via a distinct route, commonly referred to as the serrated neoplasia pathway that is typically initiated by an oncogenic BRAF mutation and is mutually exclusive with WNT activating APC mutation. In contrast to APC-induced adenomas, serrated lesions do not present with an expansion of the classical stem-cell program and retain properties related to differentiated colon epithelium9. Upon acquiring a mutation in the negative WNT pathway regulator RNF43, serrated lesions can advance into mucinous adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis upon metastasis9–12 Despite their frequent occurrence, the mechanism by which RNF43 mutations contribute to tumour progression and metastatic spread has thus far remained unclear.

Importantly, RNF43/BRAF-mutant CRC remains sensitive to inhibition of upstream WNT and EGF signalling4,13,14. Notwithstanding their WNT dependence, RNF43/BRAF-mutant tumours are characterized by relatively low levels of WNT target gene expression and high mucus production15. How these epithelial cancer subsets acquire the capacity to generate their own growth factors to drive a self-sufficient growth state remains unknown.

Here, we investigated the functional driver role of RNF43 mutations in late stage, metastasis-prone BRAF V600E-mutant mucinous adenocarcinoma. We employed CRISPR-mediated gene editing to repair RNF43 mutations in patient-derived CRC organoids, and examined consequences for cancer epithelial organization, growth factor dependencies and in vivo tumour growth and metastatic capacity. Our findings uncover a driver mechanism that involves the formation of specialized niche-factor producing cells, which permits an autonomous, pro-metastatic growth state that relies on self-organized interactions between dividing and non-dividing cancer cell populations.

sec.title: RNF43 mutation repair in patient-derived organoids eliminates metastatic capacity and niche-independent outgrowth
sec.p: To investigate whether common differences in transcriptional profiles between RNF43-mutant and APC-mutant CRC are maintained in organoid culture conditions, we compared RNAseq data of a panel of representative human patient-derived CRC organoids (Figure 1A). In agreement with previous reports6,9,15, RNF43-mutant CRC organoids displayed relatively low levels of WNT target gene expression and an increased expression of mucin-related genes (Figure 1A). To address the functional driver role of mutated RNF43, we selected the RNF43/BRAF-mutant human CRC organoid line HUB040, derived from a primary human mucinous colorectal adenocarcinoma that presented with prominent metastasis in the patient16. Different from healthy colon organoids4,13, HUB040 can be propagated without supplementation of WNT, RSPO and EGF, indicating that this tumour acquired a state of growth factor self-sufficiency (Figure 1B). As expected, based on its RNF43-mutant status, HUB040 was sensitive to treatment with Porcupine inhibitors, confirming its dependency on self-produced WNTs (Figure 1C) 4,13. We employed gene editing to correct the mutated RNF43 locus to wildtype and obtained two RNF43-corrected clones (RC1, RC2) and one non-corrected control clone (NC1) (Figures 2A and 2B). Whole genome sequencing of all clones confirmed preservation of pre-existing HUB040 driver mutations, other than RNF43 (Figure S1A). Karyotypes of HUB040, NC1 and RC2 were similar, while RC1 was somewhat divergent, mainly due to whole genome duplication (Figures S1B-G). To investigate metastatic capacity, we performed orthotopic transplantation of organoids into the caecal wall of immune-deficient mice17. After 120 days, HUB040 and NC1 had formed primary tumours that spontaneously metastasized to the lungs and the liver (Figures 2C, 2D and S2A). Strikingly, for transplanted RNF43-corrected organoids no metastatic lesions were detected (Figures 2C and 2D), even though their primary tumour load equalled that of RNF43-mutant counterparts (Figure S2A). Thus, by restoring a single mutation we eliminated the metastatic capacity of this aggressive cancer model. These data suggest a key role for mutated RNF43 in promoting metastasis.

Next, we assessed organoid niche-independency by performing single cell reconstitution assays in growth factor-depleted conditions. Like HUB040, RNF43-mutant NC1 organoids retained their capacity to expand in medium lacking extrinsic growth factors (Figures 2E, S2B and S2C). By contrast, RNF43-repaired lines RC1 and RC2 acquired a strong dependence on supplementation with WNT, RSPO and EGF (Figures 2E, S2B and S2C). These results were unexpected, as introduction of RNF43 mutations in healthy human colon-derived or mouse intestinal organoids are known to enhance WNT sensitivity10, but are not known to alter EGF dependency. Our data thus imply a role for RNF43 mutations in promoting cancer cell survival and growth in the absence of growth factor supplementation.

sec.title: Mutant RNF43 drives mucinous differentiation and niche factor production
sec.p: We next aimed to investigate how RNF43 mutations affect tumour phenotype. Transcriptome comparison of HUB40, NC1 and both RC organoid lines yielded a mutant RNF43-driven gene expression signature that comprised numerous genes encoding growth factors and mucins (Figures 3A, 3B, S2D and S2E). In line with these findings, gene sets representing Goblet and Deep Crypt Secretory (DCS) cells of healthy colon were significantly depleted from RC1 and RC2 in comparison to control lines (Figure 3C)18,19. Furthermore, RNF43-mutant tumours displayed extensive mucus secretion in vitro and in vivo, while this property was strongly diminished upon RNF43 correction (Figures 3D-F), strengthening the observation that RNF43 mutations facilitate secretory cell differentiation.

Notably, the RNF43-mutant signature comprised several reported niche factors including IGF2, VEGFA, DLL1/4 and WNT8B (Figures 3A, 3B and S2E). Blocking upstream IGF and WNT signalling diminished reconstitution capacity of HUB40 CRC organoids, which was rescued by supplementation with exogenous EGF or WNT ligands, respectively (Figures 3G and 3H), reminiscent of the growth state of RNF43-corrected organoids (Figures 2E and S2B). Based on these data, we hypothesized that RNF43 mutations accommodate the production of self-produced niche-factors that are essential for tumour survival and growth. To test this, we generated hybrid co-cultures of RNF43-mutant and RNF43-corrected organoids and monitored them over time in growth factor-depleted medium using live imaging (Figure 3I and Supplementary Videos 1-2)20. While cultures of unmixed RNF43-corrected organoids displayed a high ratio of cell death over mitotic events, this ratio was reversed when RNF43-corrected cells shared a lumen with RNF43-mutant cells (Figure 3J). These results confirm that HUB040 CRC survival relies on paracrine signalling events that are facilitated by mutant RNF43.

sec.title: Mutant RNF43 promotes tumour-intrinsic niche cell formation
sec.p: In a previous study, we showed that inactivation of Rnf43 and its paralogue Znrf3 in the mouse small intestine induces hyperplasia of stem cells as well as secretory Paneth cells, that function as an intra-epithelial stem cell niche21,22. To investigate how RNF43 mutations may promote the formation of specialized niche factor-producing cells within human CRC, we first performed single cell RNA sequencing analysis of the HUB040 organoid line. Single cell profiles spanned seven clusters with distinct expression patterns discovered by unsupervised clustering (Figures 4A and S3A). Noticeably, one population of cells (cluster 1), representing about one-sixth of tumour cells, entirely lacked expression of proliferation and stem cell-related genes23 (Figures 4B, 4C and S3B). Instead, this subset displayed prominent hallmarks of differentiated secretory niche cells, as exemplified by the expression of gene sets related to Goblet cells (Figure 4D), Deep Crypt Secretory (DCS) cells (Figure 4E)18,19, hypoxia and glycolysis (Figures S3C-E)24,25, as well as mTOR activation and the unfolded protein response (Figure S3E)26–28. We thus identified cluster 1 as a non-proliferating, niche factor-producing secretory cancer cell subset that we call tumour-intrinsic niche cells (TINCs).

Subjection of healthy colon organoids to growth factor depletion caused emergence of a TINC and DCS signature-enriched cell population, supporting the observation that TINCs share identity with differentiated, healthy DCS cells (Figure S4)18. Notably, the TINC gene signature was significantly downregulated in both RNF43-corrected clones (Figure S3F). scRNAseq analysis of all clones in complete medium revealed that 16% of both HUB040 and NC1 cells displayed high expression of the full TINC signature which was reduced to 1-7% of cells within RNF43-corrected clones (Figure 4F). In agreement, expression of prominent TINC markers was diminished in RNF43-corrected clones (Figure 4G). Based on these findings, we conclude that TINC formation is promoted by mutant RNF43.

sec.title: RNF43-mutant organoids self-organize into proliferating stem cells and non-proliferating supporting niche cells
sec.p: To characterise mutant RNF43-dependent TINC cells, we focussed on NDRG1, that we identified as a prominent marker gene for TINCs in HUB40 organoids, and for DCS cells in healthy colon organoids (Figures S3G and S4I). Introduction of an IRES-linked mNeon green fluorophore within the NDRG1 gene revealed that TINCs are heterogeneously distributed within HUB040 (Figures 4H, 4I and S5A). Non-dividing NDRG1high TINC reporter cells were interspersed with proliferative NDRG1low cells as shown by KI67 labelling (Figure 4I) and EdU incorporation (Figure 4J). Despite their differentiated and non-proliferative appearance, TINCs retained regenerative capacity, as isolated NDRG1high, NDRG1medium and NDRG1low single cells gave rise to fully grown organoids in which the heterogeneous distribution of TINCs was restored (Figures 4K and S5B). Our data thus reveal that RNF43/BRAF-mutant HUB040 CRC organoids display phenotypic heterogeneity and are capable of self-organising into a mixture of non-proliferative TINCs and stem-like cell populations.

An in-depth transcriptome characterization of sorted NDRG1high cells compared to sorted NDRG1medium and NDRG1low cells (Figures S5C-E) generated an ‘extended TINC signature’ of about 1.000 genes that robustly confirmed previously identified TINC hallmarks (Figures S5F, S5G and S3E), including mutant RNF43-dependent niche factors such as IGF2, Dll1, IGFBP2 and VEGFA (Figures 4L and 3M). Intriguingly, TINCs displayed a relatively decreased expression of WNT target genes, including RNF43 itself (Figure 4M). These results support a model in which RNF43 mutations allow for tuneable WNT signalling and intra-tumoural lineage diversification, even though all cells are RNF43-mutant. Lastly, marker genes related to regeneration (ANXA1) and metastatic relapse (EMP1) were enriched in TINCs (Figure 4M)29,30. We conclude that RNF43 mutations facilitate tumour cell differentiation into niche factor-producing cells, which explains the acquired niche-independent growth state of these tumours.

sec.title: TINCs are enriched in RNF43-mutant human CRC and metastatic lesions
sec.p: We next explored the broader relevance of TINCs for human CRC. TINC marker gene expression was significantly enriched in RNF43-mutant as well as mucinous CRC subtypes of the cancer genomics atlas (TCGA) (Figures 5A and 5B). Moreover, TINC gene expression was significantly enhanced in lung and liver metastases compared to primary colorectal tumours (Figures 5C and S6A). At the single cell level, CRC tumours were recently classified into two intrinsic epithelial subtypes6. Among these, TINC signature expression was highest in the iCMS3 group, in which RNF43 mutations are predominantly found (Figure 5D)6. Furthermore, within iCMS3 tumours, TINC signature expression was higher in RNF43-mutant compared to RNF43 wildtype cases (Figure 5D). We corroborated these findings by re-analysis of 18.320 single cell transcriptomes derived from CRC tumours of 28 patients, of which four were RNF43 mutant6 (Figure S6D). Supervised clustering with batch correction resolved eight shared CRC cell clusters. In comparison with RNF43 wildtype CRC, RNF43-mutant CRC accumulated a larger fraction of cells within two clusters (cluster 3 and 5) (Figures 5E, 5F and S6E) that were enriched for RNF43-regulated genes (Figure S6G). Additionally, cluster 5 was enriched for goblet cell markers, while TINC markers mapped to cluster 3, exemplified by high NDRG1 expression (Figures 5G and S6G). Thus, RNF43-mutant CRC subsets are not only enriched for TINC marker expression but also display an overall increased fraction of TINCs (Figure S6F).

sec.title: Tuneable WNT signalling balances the formation of stem cells and supporting tumour niche cells
sec.p: The fraction of TINCs was lowest in iCMS2 subgroups that is often driven by APC mutations and high WNT signalling (Figure 5D)6. In line, TINC marker gene expression inversely correlated with high WNT signalling and APC mutations when analysed in TCGA (Figures S6B and S6C). To investigate how APC mutations affect WNT signalling and TINC formation in context of a non-iCMS2 tumour, we introduced a conventional truncating mutation in the APC mutation cluster region of the HUB040 organoid. Surprisingly, and in contrast to healthy colon organoids31, biallelic targeting of APC was rather inefficient in HUB040 (Figure S7A), in line with the observed mutual exclusivity of APC mutations in BRAF/RNF43-mutant human cancers32. Compared to HUB040APC+/- clones that we obtained, HUB040APC-/- organoid clones displayed prominent WNT/β-catenin target gene expression, enhanced nuclear β-catenin levels and acquired resistance to treatment with WNT secretion inhibitors (Figures 6A, 6B and S7B-D). Furthermore, introduction of truncated APC induced enrichment of gene signatures representing transit amplifying (TA) cells and stem-like cells, while secretory cell profiles and the TINC signature were significantly reduced (Figures 6C and 6D)33. Single cell analysis revealed that introduction of an APC mutation shifted HUB040 cell identity and composition, as shown by an increased fraction of WNT-high cells and a reduced fraction of cells expressing the TINC signature (Figures 6E, 6F and S7E-G). These alterations were not compatible with efficient growth, as HUB040APC-/- organoids were outcompeted by HUB040APCwt organoids during co-culture (Figure 6G). We conclude that APC mutations, in context of a BRAF/RNF43-mutant tumour background, interfere with intra-epithelial niche formation that is otherwise facilitated by mutant RNF43.

We hypothesized that adjustable levels of WNT signalling are vital for BRAF/RNF43-mutant tumour self-organising capacity. Indeed, constitutive pharmacological activation of WNT signalling (CHIR99021) was not tolerated by HUB040 organoids (Figure 6H). Furthermore, HUB040 organoids treated with WNT inhibitors for 24 and 48 hours (Figures S7H-J) revealed an incremental downregulation of proliferative, stem and TA signatures and an increase in differentiation signatures, including TINC (Figures 6C and 6D). In line with these findings, the number and brightness of TINC reporter cells in HUB040 increased upon WNT inhibitor treatment (Figures 6I and S7K). Thus, although BRAF/RNF43-mutant mucinous cancers are wired towards lower levels of WNT signalling that are optimal to facilitate secretory differentiation, a threshold of WNT signalling in a subset of cancer cells is still required to prevent terminal differentiation and maintain self-renewal of proliferative cells (Figure 6J).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Self-organisation principles promote tumour progression in CRC34–41, but thus far the underlying genetic driver events remained poorly understood. In this study, we show that RNF43 mutations facilitate the generation of TINCs, tumour-intrinsic NDRG1high/VEGFAhigh niche cells that secrete essential growth factors to drive proliferation and survival of adjacent stem-like cancer cells. Despite their differentiated, non-proliferative phenotype, TINCs retain phenotypic plasticity and can give rise to full-blown tumour structures.

Different from classical APC mutations that promote uniform high WNT signalling and endow tumour cells with stem-like properties, we find that mutant RNF43 permits for tuneable WNT activity, which enables tumour cells to pick diverging phenotypic states. Accordingly, RNF43 mutations drive a growth state that relies on interactions between dividing and non-dividing cancer cell populations (Figure 6K). This role of mutant RNF43 is reminiscent of the concomitant hyperplasia of stem cells and Paneth niche cells induced by co-deletion of Rnf43/Znrf3 from the mouse small intestine21. In human colon cancer development, however, RNF43 mutations arise after tumour-initiating BRAF mutations9,10,32. Consistently, our results indicate that RNF43 mutations are crucial for metastatic spread, but not for tumour initiation. As both niche independency and phenotypic plasticity correlate with metastatic capacity in CRC4,38,40,41, it is tempting to speculate that mutant RNF43-mediated TINC formation is a prerequisite for metastasis to distant organs. In line with this assumption, we find that TINC profiles are enhanced in metastatic samples of mucinous human CRC.

Strikingly, introduction of APC mutations in a BRAF/RNF43-mutant context suppresses TINC formation and is not beneficial for growth of this tumour subtype, indicating that cancer driver activity of WNT mutations relies on a specific mutational context. Furthermore, the dependence of BRAF/RNF43-mutant tumours on adjustable WNT signalling for establishing a tumour-intrinsic niche offers an opportunity for pharmacological interference. While constitutive enhancement of WNT signalling in these tumours precludes niche formation and growth factor self-sufficiency, inhibition of WNT pushes terminal differentiation and stem cell depletion. Notwithstanding the clear regulatory role of WNT, other pathways may play a role in TINC formation. RNF43 truncating mutations were recently linked to activation of the PI3K-Akt-mTOR pathway42, which also mediates activation of cellular programs linked to glycolysis and hypoxia43, as well as Goblet and Paneth cell differentiation in the mouse intestine and human intestinal organoids27,28,44,45.

Additionally, we demonstrate that RNF43 mutations are causative to a mucinous CRC phenotype. How excessive mucus production links to cancer development and metastasis formation remains incompletely understood46, although roles in immune evasion, growth factor trapping and chemoprotection were proposed47. We expect that formation of an intra-tumoral pro-metastatic mucinous niche is relevant for other RNF43-mutant human cancers with mucinous histology, including intraductal mucinous carcinoma of the pancreas and mucinous ovarian cancer48–50.

In summary, our study demonstrates that genetic correction of putative driver genes in patient-derived organoids is a powerful approach to examine the mechanistic role of these mutations in an advanced human cancer context. Our findings predict that RNF43-mediated tumor-intrinsic niche formation is a broad concept in cancer biology, and that a comprehensive understanding of the pathways and mechanisms underlying tumour niche self-organization are likely to provide insights that may be harnessed to help limit disease progression and metastatic recurrence.

sec.title: Patient material
sec.p: The collection of colorectal tissue for the generation of healthy colon and CRC organoids was performed according to the guidelines of the European Network of Research Ethics Committees (EUREC) following European, national and local law. In all cases, patients signed informed consent after ethical committees approved the study protocols. Organoids identified by HUB codes HUB-02-B2-040 (HUB040, CRC) and HUB-02-A2-040 (HUB040N, normal colon) are catalogued at https://huborganoids.nl/ and can be requested at info@huborganoids.nl. Distribution to third (academic or commercial) parties will have to be authorized by the Biobank Research Ethics Committee of the University Medical Center Utrecht (TCBio) at request of Hubrecht Organoid Technology (HUB). P26T (CRC) was established in a previous study.13

sec.title: Organoid culture
sec.p: Healthy colon organoids and CRC organoids were cultured according to previous protocols13. In short, organoids were cultured in drops of Matrigel (Corning) or BME (R&D systems), and the medium was refreshed every two or three days. CRC organoids were passaged using TrypLE Express (Life Technologies) incubation at 37 °C. Healthy colon organoid were passaged using mechanical shearing (pipetting). Healthy colon organoids were cultured in advanced DMEM/F12 medium (Invitrogen), supplemented with 1% Penicillin/Streptomycin (P/S, Lonza), 1% Hepes buffer (Invitrogen), 1% Glutamax (Invitrogen), 1x B27 (Invitrogen), 10 mM Nicotinamide (Sigma-Aldrich), 1.25 mM N-acetylcysteine (Sigma-Aldrich), 50 ng/mL EGF (PeproTech), 500 nM TGF-b type I receptor inhibitor A83-01 (Tocris), 10 μM P38 inhibitor SB202190 (Sigma-Aldrich), 50% Wnt3a-CM (homemade) or 1% surrogate WNT-CM (homemade)53, 10% Noggin-CM (homemade), 20% Rspo1-CM (homemade) and 100 μg/mL Primocin (Invitrogen) (full medium). Colorectal carcinoma organoids were cultured in medium without EGF, WNT and RSPO (CRC medium), unless stated otherwise. RNF43-corrected (RC), non-corrected (NC) HUB040 clones were maintained in full HCO medium to prevent negative selection against growth factor dependence.

sec.title: CRISPR strategy and design
sec.p: To correct the RNF43 P441fs mutation back to wildtype, HUB040 organoids were electroporated with a single stranded HDR template (ss-oligo) and Cas9-gRNA. The ss-oligo was designed according to previously established optimal rules.54,55 Briefly, the RNF43 mutation in HUB040 is a five base pair duplication, which was corrected in the template. The template was an asymmetric template oligo complementary to the non-target strand overlapping the Cas9 cut site with 36 bp extension on the PAM-distal side, and with a 91-bp extension on the PAM-proximal side of the break. The ss-oligo was ordered at Integrated DNA Technologies with phosphorothioate modifications of the last two nucleotide bonds at the 3’ and 5’ end (sequence:

TATGCACAAGGCTGGGGAATGAGCCACCTCCAATCCACCTCACAGCACCCTGCTG CTTGCCCAGTGCCCCTACGCCGGGCCAGGCCTCCAGACAGCAGTGGATCTGGAGA AAGCTATTGCACAGAACGC). A gRNA was chosen using the Benchling tool (https://benchling.com) that created a double stranded break close to the mutation (sequence: CCAGATCCACTGCTGTCAGG) and cloned in pSpCas9(BB)-2A-Puro (Addgene, 48139).
APC mutations were introduced by targeting the mutation cluster region (MCR) in the APC gene using previously reported gRNA (sequence: TACATCTGCTAAACATGAG).31

Reporter targeting vector was generated by altering HR180-LGR5-iCT plasmid (Addgene #129094) into a plasmid compatible with insertion of homology arms using golden-gate cloning56. iCaspase-T2A-tdTomato sequence was removed and swapped for mNeonGreen-NLS using a combination of Q5® High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase and the In-Fusion HD Cloning kit (Takara). Final targeting vector was generated by insertion of homology arms (~600bp each) flanking the targeted region downstream of NDRG1 to obtain the NDRG1-specific IRES-mNeonGreen-NLS-WPRE-bGHpA-EF1-Ruby-T2A-Puro-SV40pA targeting plasmid. gRNAs were cloned into pSpCas9(BB)-2A-Puro using golden gate cloning (sequence: CCGGACTCTGATCTCTGTAG)).)).

sec.title: Electroporation
sec.p: Organoid electroporation was performed as previously described57. Briefly, organoids were grown in antibiotic-free medium including 10 μM Y-27632 (Selleck chemicals) for two days before electroporation. 24 hours before electroporation, 1.25% DMSO was added to the culture medium. For electroporation, the NEPA21 electroporator was used with the configuration reported by Fujii et al.57. For RNF43 correction and generation of TINC-reporter, 5 μg of Cas9-gRNA and 5 μg template were transfected. For other CRISPR targeting, 10 μg of Cas9-gRNA was transfected. Organoids were recovered for two days by adding medium supplemented with 10 μM Y-27632. From five days post-electroporation organoids were grown in full medium. For CRISPR-engineered organoids, single clones were established by manual picking of individual organoids derived from single cells and genotyped. Reporter lines were selected by puromycin treatment and sorted for the constitutive mRuby fluorophore and single cell derived clones were picked manually and genotyped.

sec.title: Genotyping
sec.p: For genotyping of genome-edited organoids, genomic DNA was isolated using QIAamp DNA micro kit (Qiagen). PCR amplification performed using using GoTaq Flexi DNA polymerase (Promega) and products were loaded on an agarose gel. Gel fragments of expected sizes were isolated using QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen) and sequenced by Sanger sequencing. Knockout and Knockin efficiencies were determined using the TIDE58 (http://shinyapps.datacurators.nl/tide/) and TIDER59 (http://shinyapps.datacurators.nl/tider/) tools respectively. Manual verification of genotypes for clonal lines was done in Benchling.
HUB040 NDRG1-IRES-mNeon clonal organoid lines were genotyped to confirm homozygous integration of the knock-in construct using gel electrophoresis of PCR products.
Primers used for genotyping are listed in Supplementary Table 1.

sec.title: Whole-Genome Sequencing and mapping
sec.p: Genomic DNA of naïve HUB040 and clonal organoid lines was isolated using QIAamp DNA micro kit (Qiagen) and DNA libraries for Illumina sequencing were generated by using standard protocols (Illumina) Libraries were sequenced on a NovaSeq 6000 S4 platform with 2 x 150 bp read length to 30 times base coverage.

Sequencing reads were mapped against human reference genome GRCh38 by using Burrows-Wheeler Aligner v0.7.17 mapping tool60 with settings ‘bwa mem -c 100 -M’. Sequence reads were marked for duplicates by using Sambamba61 v0.6.8 and sequence read quality scores were recalibrated with GATK62 BaseRecalibrator v2.7.2. CNVs detection was performed with Control-FREEC63 v11.56. Full pipeline description and settings are also available at: https://github.com/UMCUGenetics/IAP.

sec.title: Mutation calling and filtering
sec.p: Mutation calling and filtering was performed on multi-sample vcfs generated by IAP using HaplotypeCaller from GATK v.4.1.3.0. GATK’s VariantFiltration was used for variant quality evaluation with options: “--filter-expression ‘QD < 2.0’ --filter-expression ‘MQ < 40.0’ --filterexpression ‘FS > 60.0’ --filter-expression ‘HaplotypeScore > 13.0’ --filter-expression ‘MQRankSum < -12.5’ --filter-expression ‘ReadPosRankSum < -8.0’ --filter-expression ‘MQ0 >= 4 && ((MQ0 / (1.0 * DP)) > 0.1)’ --filter-expression ‘DP < 5’ --filter-expression ‘QUAL < 30’ --filter-expression ‘QUAL >= 30.0 && QUAL < 50.0’ --filter-expression ‘SOR > 4.0’ -filter-name ‘SNP_LowQualityDepth’ --filter-name ‘SNP_MappingQuality’ --filter-name ‘SNP_StrandBias’ --filter-name ‘SNP_HaplotypeScoreHigh’ --filter-name ‘SNP_MQRankSumLow’ --filter-name ‘SNP_ReadPosRankSumLow’ --filter-name ‘SNP_HardToValidate’ --filter-name ‘SNP_LowCoverage’ --filter-name ‘SNP_VeryLowQual’ --filter-name ‘SNP_LowQual’ --filter-name ‘SNP_SOR’ -cluster 3 -window 10”.
Subsequently, SNPEffFilter64, SNPSiftDbnsfp (database dbNSFP3.2a65;, GATK VariantAnnotator (database COSMIC v.89), and SNPSiftAnnotate (database GoNL release 5) were used for variant annotation.

Finally, to obtain catalogues of high-quality somatic mutation calls, we applied post-processing filtering steps, per sample, as described below (all scripts are available at: https://github.com/ToolsVanBox/SMuRF).

Briefly, only variants were considered if present on autosomal chromosomes, passed VariantFiltration with a GATK phred-scaled quality score ≥ 100, had a base coverage of at least 10X, had a mapping quality (MQ) score of 60, did no overlap with single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Database v146 and a panel of unmatched normal human MSC and fetal genomes (BED-file available upon request), had a GATK genotype score (GQ) of 99 (indel/sbs in clonal sample, or indel in paired control) or higher than 10 (sbs in paired control), had a variant allele frequency (VAF) of >=0.1 to exclude in vitro accumulated mutations.

sec.title: Identification of driver mutations
sec.p: Single base substitutions or indels were considered as driver mutations when they have a MQ of 30, a minimal base coverage of 10x, had a VAF equal or higher than 0.1, or present in driver genes COSMIC cancer gene consensus (version of 9/5/2019), were also annotated as missense, frameshift, stop-gain, insertion or deletion, had either a high or moderate expected effect as annotated by SnpEff, and were not present in the Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Database v146 and a panel of unmatched normal human MSC and fetal genomes (BED-file available upon request). Oncoplot (Figure S1A) was generated with the ComplexHeatmap66 v2.12.0 package from Bioconductor.
Structural variant and chromosomal copy-number alteration calling was performed using the GRIDSS-purple-linx67 pipeline developed at the Hartwig Medical Foundation.

sec.title: In vivo subcutaneous tumorigenesis
sec.p: Animal experiments were approved by the Competent Authority, The Netherlands (License number AVD115002016614), which is advised by the Animal Ethics Committee. Animal work protocol (614-1-22) was approved by the Animal Welfare Body and were performed in accordance with the Dutch Law on Animal Experiments and the European Directive 2010/63/EU. Healthy 8–10 week old 25–30 g male NOD.Cg-Prkdcscid Il2rgtm1Wjl/SzJ (NSG) mice were supplied by Charles River. Animals were randomly allocated in groups of three mice into individually ventilated cages. Animals were kept at room temperature under 12 hours light/dark cycles and received standard chow pellets and water ad libitum. HUB040 organoids were dissociated five days after passaging into single-cells by TrypLE Express incubation for 5 min at 37 °C. A cell-matrigel (1:1) suspension was prepared with 5 × 106 cells/mL. Using a 1 mL syringe and 25G 0.5 × 16 mm needles, 100 μl of the suspension were subcutaneously injected into the right flank of animals. Animal welfare was monitored by physical appearance, behaviour, and body weight. Animals were sacrificed when the tumour volume (V) reached 1.5 mm3, as measured by V = 1/2 × (smaller diameter2 × larger diameter). Tumour tissue was harvested for further immunohistochemical analyses. Sample sizes are outlined in the figure legends. Mice were randomly assigned to experimental groups. No blinding method was used for injection. No animals were excluded from downstream analysis.

sec.title: Orthotopic implantation in the caecum of NSG mice
sec.p: In order to evaluate the tumourigenic capacity of the organoids, murine orthotopic caecum-implantation model17 was used as described in animal work protocol (614-1-22). In summary, day before implantation, HUB040 organoids were dissociated into single cells and 2.5 × 105 cells were plated in 10 μL drops of neutralized Rat Tail High Concentrated Type I Collagen (Corning, C3867). Cultures were allowed to recover overnight at 37 °C, 5% (vol/vol) CO2. NSG mice were treated with a s.c. dose of Carprofen (5 mg/kg, Rimadyl™) 30 min before surgery and were subsequently sedated by using isoflurane inhalation anesthesia [~2% (vol/vol) isoflurane/O2 mixture]. The caecum was exteriorized through a midline abdominal incision and a single collagen drop containing organoids was surgically transplanted in the cecal submucosa. Carprofen was administrated s.c. post 24 hour surgery. Animal welfare was monitored by physical appearance, behaviour, and body weight. Power analyses were carried out prior to experiments being carried out to determine the minimum number of animals required for each experiment. These analyses were informed by previous and / or preliminary experiments. Animals were house vested in groups of four. Every group (i.e. cage) contained mixture of mice transplanted with both organoid genotypes. No animals were excluded from downstream analysis. The biotechnician was blinded to the group allocation of the animals during the experiment.

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry (IHC)
sec.p: Mouse tissues with or without organoid-initiated tumours/metastases were fixed in 4% formaldehyde solution and paraffin embedded. Sections of 4 μm thickness were made. Prior to the staining, tissue sections were deparaffinized and rehydrated. Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked with 1.5% hydrogen peroxide for 30 min. Heat-induced antigen retrieval was carried out using citrate buffer pH6.0 for 20 min, followed by the cooling of tissue sections for 20 min. Sections were incubated overnight at 4 °C with primary antibodies (anti-hNucleoli clone NM95, Abcam (ab190710) 1:1000 and anti-Mucin2 clone (H-300), Santa Cruz (sc-15334), 1:100) diluted in PBS with 0.1% Sodium azide and 3% BSA. The next day, sections were washed three times with 0.05% Tween-PBS solution for 5 min, followed by a 1 hour incubation with the HRP-conjugated secondary antibody. Subsequently, sections were washed three times with 1× PBS for 5 min and developed with 3,3’-Diaminobenzidine (DAB) chromogen for 10 min at room temperature in the dark. Sections were rinsed under running tap water for 10 min and counterstained with hematoxylin, followed by dehydration and mounting.

Stainings were scanned using NanoZoomerXR whole slide scanner (Hamamatsu) at 40X magnification, with a resolution of 0.25 μm/pixel. Quantification of the scans was performed using QuPath program analysis program68. Target of interest (tumour or distinct immune populations) was quantified using QuPath’s Trained Pixel classification command that allows an automated recognition of background, tissue (hematoxylin) and DAB staining areas. The percentage of target of interest area was then calculated by using the following formula: DAB area / (DAB + tissue− background area) * 100.

sec.title: Reconstitution assays using growth factor and drug treatments
sec.p: Single cells from organoid were harvested using TrypLE incubation at 37 °C. Cells were filtered through a 40 μm nylon cell strainer (Falcon). Cells were counted and seeded in a 1*106 cells / mL dilution in Matrigel/BME. Cultures were incubated in standard culture medium with indicated additions/depletions of factors and drugs, which was replenished every 2-3 days. After seven days, brightfield images were taken using an EVOS imaging system and organoids were split 1:2 similar as mentioned before, after which outgrowth was monitored again for seven days. Quantitative viability assays were performed by CellTiter-Glo® (Promega) or Alamar Blue® (Thermo Fisher) according to manufacturer instructions. Pictures are shown for a representative experiment, which was performed at least three times. Normalized viability data was combined from multiple experiments and two or three technical replicates per experiment.

sec.title: Bulk RNA sequencing
sec.p: Organoids were lysed in RLT lysis buffer (Qiagen) + 1% β-mercapto-ethanol; seven days after passaging. Biological triplicates were employed that were passaged and lysed at separate moments. For the LGK-974 experiments, organoids were treated with 100 nM LGK-974 or a DMSO volume control for 24 or 48 hours prior to lysis. RNA was obtained using the Qiagen QiaSymphony SP (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Library prep was performed using Truseq RNA stranded polyA (Illumina). Libraries were sequenced on an Illumina NextSeq2000 platform with 1x50bp reads. Single-end RNASeq reads were processed using the UMCU RNASeq pipeline (v2.3.0) with default settings. Read quality was assessed by FastQC (0.11.4) followed by splice-aware alignment against the human reference genome (GRCh38) with STAR69 (2.4.2a). RNA expression quantification was performed with htseq-count (0.6.0) in reverse-stranded mode. Differential gene expression analysis was performed with the DESeq270 (1.22.2) R package. In each comparison, genes were selected with an absolute fold-change > 1.5 and p adjusted < 0.05. Generation of heatmaps and scatterplots was done in using the pHeatmap and ggplot2 R packages.

sec.title: GSEA and gene signatures
sec.p: Gene set enrichment analyses (GSEA) were performed using the Broad Institute GSEA tool (software.broadinstitute.org/gsea/index.jsp) with default settings, including permutation by gene sets. HALLMARK genesets were derived from the Molecular Signatures Database.71 Geneset for REG4+ deep crypt secretory cells (DCSs) was defined as human orthologues (identified by bioDBnet) of the >2 fold upregulated genes with a p-value < 0.05 in Reg+ cells compared to Lgr5+ cells that were previously reported.18 Gene sets for human colon specific cell types were derived from a published single-cell transcriptome study (Wang et al. table S2).19 Genesets for HUB040 single cell clusters were defined by marker gene analysis using the ‘FindAllMarkers’ command in Seurat comparing one cluster to all other clusters using a wilcox test. Threshold for adjusted p-value was set at p < 0.05. The WNT signature was reported previously by Van der Flier et al.52

For the analysis of secretory genes, a list of secreted proteins was downloaded from human protein atlas (“Secreted proteins predicted by MDSEC”)72. Downregulated secretory genes were defined as: significantly downregulated in at least three comparisons and not upregulated in the other comparison (RC1 vs HUB040, RC2 vs HUB040, RC1 vs NC1, RC2 vs NC1)

sec.title: Single cell RNA sequencing and analysis
sec.p: Single cells from organoid were harvested using TrypLE incubation at 37 °C, seven days after passaging. Cells were filtered through a 40 μm nylon cell strainer (Falcon). scRNA-seq was performed according to the Sort-seq protocol73. Libraries were sequenced on an Illumina NextSeq500 at paired-end 60- and 26-bp read length and 75,000 reads per cell.

Reads were mapped to the hg38 reference genome. Analysis was performed with the R-package Seurat74 (4.0.4). Cells with 400-50000 unique features and 1000-7000 total transcript counts were included in the analysis. Scores for gene signature expression were calculated using the AddModuleScore function.
Signature enrichment in marker gene lists was determined using the Enrichr tool75 (https://maayanlab.cloud/Enrichr/).

To analyse fraction of TINCs in RNF43-corrected and non-corrected clones, cells were filtered according to previously mentioned settings and for each cell a module score for the original TINC signature was calculated. Cells with a module score > 0.61 were scored as TINC, which corresponded to 16% of cells in the HUB040 naïve sample (which was the fraction of cells mapping to cluster 1 in the original analysis). Data was plotted using ggplot2.

To validate the TINC signature in a human cohort, published RNAseq data of tumour epithelial cells of colorectal cancer patients were used6. Twenty RNF43 wildtype patients from iCMS2 cohort based on single-cell RNA sequencing and inferred CNV result and four RNF43 mutant patients were selected. After selecting patients, supervised clustering using 154 TINC signature genes was performed with batch correction using harmony algorithm76 to remove patient specificity. Differential gene expression analysis was performed using the ‘FindAllMarkers’ command in Seurat with logistic regression framework.

sec.title: TCGA data analysis
sec.p: Signature scores for indicated gene sets were calculated for each samples as log2 Z-score over the total TCGA Colon Adenocarcinoma set (rpkm values of 382 samples - cbcoad) using the R2 genomic analysis platform (http://r2.amc.nl). TINC signature was determined as the top 25 marker genes for cluster 1 in HUB040 (from Seurat marker gene analysis). RNF43 mutation status was determined by combining the list of RNF43 mutant TCGA samples (derived from C-bioportal) combined with results of re-analysis by Gianakkis et al.32 calling additional mutations that were falsely labelled as polymerase slipping errors in the original TCGA analysis.32 CMS classifications were derived from the Colorectal Cancer Subtyping Consortium (CRCSC)77, samples without CMS label have been left out of the analysis. Classification as mucinous was derived from Cancer Type in cbioportal (mucinous adenocarcinoma of colon and rectum). “High and low WNT” was defined as the upper and lower quartile of the Z-scores for the intestinal WNT/TCF signature as reported by Van der Flier et al.52.

sec.title: Immunofluorescence
sec.p: For staining of Mucin2, organoids were seeded in 15-well IBIDI angiogenesis chambers during passaging and fixed 7-12 days later in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) (Sigma-Aldrich) for 60 min at room temperature. The fixation was quenched using 0.05 M NH4Cl and cells were permeabilised with PBD0.2T (48,5mL PBS, 1mL 10%Triton, 0,5mL DMSO and 0,5g BSA) for 20 min at room temperature. The organoids were incubated with primary antibodies diluted

in PBD0.2T at 4 °C overnight. Washes were performed with PBD0.2T after which secondary antibodies were incubated for 3h at room temperature. Stained organoids were mounted using IBIDI mounting medium.

For other stainings, organoids were cultured as usual. 7-12 days after passaging, matrix was removed using dispase (Invitrogen) and organoids were transferred to 8-well IBIDI imaging slide. Fixation, permeabilisation and antibody staining were performed inside the imaging slide, as indicated above, except for primary antibody incubations were performed for one hour at room temperature. Stained organoids were mounted using IBIDI mounting medium.

The following antibodies and dyes have been used for immunofluorescence: Mouse-anti-Mucin2 (sc-515032, Santa Cruz, 1:200), Mouse-anti-β-catenin (610154, BD Transduction Laboratories, 1:200), Rabbit-anti-KI67 (ab15580, Abcam, 1:200), Goat-anti-Mouse-Alexa-488 (A11029, Invitrogen, 1:600) Goat-anti-Rabbit-Alexa-647 (A21245, Invitrogen, 1:600), Phalloidin-Alexa-647 (8940S, CST, 1:200) and Dapi (D9542, Sigma, 1:1.000). Images were acquired with a Zeiss LSM700 confocal microscope.

Image processing was performed using FIJI (2.3.0). Nuclear β-catenin and TINC-reporter intensity were quantified using the StarDist plugin (0.8.3)78 with the Dapi staining used for single nucleus segmentation. Data was analysed and plotted in R.

sec.title: Hybrid organoid co-culture, time-lapse imaging and analysis
sec.p: The protocol on generating hybrid organoid co-cultures has been described previously20. In short: HUB040 naïve organoids were transduced with mCherry tagged H2B constructs and HUB040 RC2 organoids with mNeon green tagged H2B constructs and selected by FACS sorting. Six days post splitting, both lines were starved in CRC medium for 24 hours and at day 7 broken up into small clumps of cells that were mixed in 1:1 ratio. Cells were concentrated by centrifugation, resuspended in a small volume of CRC medium and incubated at 37 °C for 30 min Cell aggregates were plated in 10 μL BME droplets in an 18 Well μ-Slide (IBIDI #81811). Three days after plating, time-lapse microscopy was performed on an inverted LSM880 Fast AiryScan scanning confocal microscope (Zeiss) using LSM scanning mode with a 488nm Argon-laser and 561nm Diode-laser, equipped with a 20X dry immersion objective (Objective Plan-Apochromat 20x/0.8 M27, Zeiss). Cells were kept in CRC medium at 37°C under 5% CO2 for the full duration of the experiment. Images were acquired with a Z-interval of 5μm covering the full volume of the organoid and time-interval of one hour for a total duration on 60 hours. Time-lapse images were processed and analysed following a previously described pipeline in which depth-encoded movies were generated in which cell divisions and cell dead events were scored79. The cell death / mitosis ratio was calculated as a proxy for organoid survival. Cell numbers at the start of time-lapse were counted using Imaris software (Andor version 9.9.1). Videos and snapshots of 3D-reconstructed representative organoids were made in Imaris.

sec.title: Flow cytometry analysis and sorting of organoids
sec.p: Single cells from organoid were harvested using TrypLE incubation at 37 °C. Cells were filtered through a 40 μm nylon cell strainer (Falcon) and live-cells were measured at a FACS Celesta with FACS Diva software (BD). The following fluorescent channels were used: BB515 for mNeon, PE-CF594 for mRuby and PE-Cy5 for Alexa-647 labelled Edu.

EdU incorporation assays were performed by culturing organoids in CRC medium containing 10 μM EdU for 16 hours to cells, after which single cells were harvested, fixed in 4% PFA and EdU-labeling was performed according to manufacturer instructions (Click-iT EdU Cell Proliferation Kit for Imaging, Thermo Fisher).

Sorting of TINC-reporter populations was performed using a FACS Aria III machine (BD) Populations were gated for viable single cells which were divided in three equal populations of 20-30% of the total based on mNeon histogram (example in Figure S5A). Sorted cells were directly lysed in RLT lysis buffer (Qiagen) for RNAseq analysis, or taken in culture for organoid reconstitution, by seeding in a 1x106 cells / mL dilution in BME.
Gated single cells were analysed in FlowJo (version 10.6.1).

sec.title: Western blot
sec.p: Organoids were collected in Cell Recovery Solution (Corning), incubated for 20 min on ice and subsequently lysed in RIPA buffer containing protease and phosphatase inhibitors. Lysates were boiled in 1x SDS sample buffer and ran on a pre-casted SDS-page gel (Mini protean, BIORAD). Gels were transferred to a Immobilon-FL PVDF membranes (Millipore), which was blocked for 1 hour at room temperature in 1:1 ratio Odyssey blocking buffer (LI-COR): PBS, and stained against APC (sc-7930, Santa Cruz, 1:1.000) and Actin (691001, MP, 1:10.000) overnight at 4 °C. Blots were stained with secondary antibodies IRDye-680 goat anti-rabbit (926-32221, LI-COR, 1:10.000) and IRDye-800 goat anti-mouse (925-68070, LI-COR, 1:10.000) for 1 hour at room temperature in the dark. The Typhoon (GE Healthcare) infrared imaging system was used for immunoblot analysis.

sec.title: RT-qPCR
sec.p: Organoids, seven days after passaging, or FACS-sorted cell populations were lysed in RLT lysis buffer (Qiagen) + 1% β-mercapto-ethanol and RNA was purified using the RNeasy kit (Qiagen) according to manufacturer’s protocol. RNA was used as a template for cDNA production using the iScript™ cDNA Synthesis Kit (Biorad) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. The synthesized cDNA was subsequently used in a qRT–PCR using IQ SYBR green mix (Biorad) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Used primers are listed in Supplementary Table 2
Expression of WNT target genes was corrected against house-keeping gene GAPDH and normalized to the control.

sec.title: APC competition assay
sec.p: HUB040 and HUB040APC-/- organoids were split into single cells, counted and seeded in a 1:1 ratio. Mixed organoid populations were passaged once a week, and during each passage, genomic DNA was harvested for genotyping the fraction of APC mutant alleles as indicated above.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: For RNA sequencing analysis, statistical significance was determined using the DESeq function in R, which uses a Wald test (two-tailed), see detailed methods. Gene set enrichment was performed as described in the methods. For other data, p values were calculated using the ‘stat_compare_means’ function of the ggpubr package (0.40.0) in R. For comparing two or more groups of non-parametric data, a two-sample Wilcoxon test or Kruskal-Wallis were used respectively.

sec.p: The scRNA-seq and bulk RNA-seq data generated in this study are available from Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) under the accession codes GSE213079 (scRNAseq), GSE213077 (bulk RNAseq various organoid lines), GSE212959 (bulk RNAseq RNF43-corrected and non-corrected HUB040 organoids), GSE220128 (bulk RNAseq TINC reporter cells), GSE213068 (bulk RNAseq APC mutant and wildtype HUB040 organoids) and GSE213072 (bulk RNAseq HUB040 organoids treated with LGK-974).

Violin plot showing single cell module scores for expression of genes from the TINC signature grouped by cluster.

caption.title: A tight window of WNT signalling balances tumour niche cells and stem cells.
caption.p: A. Representative confocal microscopy pictures of organoids with IF labelling for β-catenin. Scale bar = 20 μm. B. Violin plot showing quantification of nuclear β-catenin signal for 205-231 cells per organoid line. C, d. Results of GSEA analysis comparing HUB040APC-/- with HUB040 (WNT activation, blue) and HUB040 treated with 100 nM LGK-974 for 24 or 48 hours with DMSO treatment (WNT inhibition, orange and green) by gene signatures of colon-specific cell types18,19 (C) or HUB040-specific clusters as determined in Figure 3a (D). x-axis shows the normalized enrichment score (NES) and size of the dots shows the false discovery rate (FDR). E. Violin plots showing single cell module scores for expression of genes from the HUB040 TINC signature grouped by organoid line of origin. F. Scatter plot showing inverse relation between single cell module scores for expression of genes from the HUB040 TINC signature and the Van der Flier WNT signature52. Colour of dots indicates line of origin. G. Line graph showing fraction of APC mutant DNA after each passage in the competition assay of indicated lines. n = 3. H. Box plots showing the relative viability of HUB040 organoids after 14 days treatment with 5 μM CHIR99021 or DMSO control. n = 3 per condition. I. Representative confocal microscopy images of HUB040 NDRG1-IRES-mNeon (TINC reporter) organoids after three days treatment with LGK-974 or DMSO control. Scale bar = 50 μm. J. Schematic representation of the optimal window of WNT-signalling for fitness of colorectal mucinous adenocarcinomas. K. Diagram of the biological model presented in the discussion comparing two routes towards of niche-independency in cancer.
